001. 29 April 1893

Ulsterville, Belfast (4000)

Irish League (3) 3-2 (0) Scottish League

Gls: IL Peden 3, Williamson, Torrans; SL Lang 65, Brown

Gordon (Linfield); Stewart (Cliftonville), Torrans (Linfield), McKeown (Linfield), Milne (Linfield), Johnston (Glentoran), McLaughlin (Ulster), Torrens (Linfield), Williamson (Cliftonville), Seddington (Glentoran), Peden (Linfield)

Gaffikin in announced line-up made way for T.A. Torrans

Scotland used a substitute in the first half, Wylie retiring hurt to be replaced by Brown who later scored.

* also listed as 3-0 win for the Irish League.

International, Inter-League, at Ulsterville (Belfast).

Irish League – Scottish League 3-2 (3-0).

Attendance: 3,000; gate receipt: £80.

Referee: Mr. John James Bentley (EFL); linesmen: Messrs. W. Potter (IFA) and Lawrence (SFL).

Scottish League (2-3-5): Jock Fairbairn (Hearts), Andrew Thomson (Captain; Third Lanark), Archie McCall (Renton), James Kirkwood (Abercorn), J.L. Allison (Renton), Edward McBain (St. Mirren), Alex McLardy (Abercorn), Alex Wylie (St. Mirren), Robert Laing (Leith Athletic), James McCall (Renton), David Baird (Hearts).

The goals: 1-0 Peden (3 min.), 2-0 Williamson (10 min.), 3-0 S. Torrans, 3-1 Laing, 3-2 Brown.

Substitute for Scottish League: Andy Brown (St Mirren) replaced Alex Wylie after 6 minutes’ play due to injury.

004. 02 February 1895

Grosvenor Park, Belfast (6000)

Irish League (1) 1-4 (3) Scottish League

Thompson (Distillery); Gordon (Linfield), Torrens (Linfield), Ponsonby (Distillery), Milne (Linfield), Burnett (Glentoran), Morrison (Glentoran), Hall (Glentoran), Stanfield (Distillery), Jordan (Linfield), McAllen (Linfield)

The annual inter-League match between Ireland and Scotland, which falls to be played at Belfast tomorrow, does not appear to be exciting an unusual amount of interest, and I don’t suppose many care seriously whether the Thistle or the Shamrock triumphs.

The Scottish League have always looked upon the fixture as a second-rate affair, and treated it accordingly; and although the team for this occasion can scarcely be called a secondary one, it certainly cannot be considered first-class. Of the two previous games one was won by the Irishmen and one by the Scotsmen, so that tomorrow’s will partake of the nature of the rubber.

The Scottish eleven will show two changes from the original selection – Marshall (Rangers) and Butter (Dundee) being substituted by Goldie and Connell, of St. Mirrren.

The teams will therefore be:

Scotland. – John Patrick (St. Mirren), Tom Dunbar (Celtic), Willie Gibson (Rangers), Hugh Goldie (St. Mirren), James Kelly (Celtic), W. Thomson (Dumbarton), J. Taylor (St. Mirren), L. Bell (Third Lanark), J. Madden (Celtic), J. Connell (St. Mirren), John Barker (Rangers).

Ireland. – Jimmy Thompson (Distillery), Gibson (Cliftonville), Sam Torrans (Linfield), Jack Ponsonby (Distillery), Robert Milne (Linfield), John Burnett (Glentoran), Tom Morrison (Glentoran), George Hall (Glentoran), Olphert Stanfield (Distillery), Tom Jordan (Linfield), Joe McAllen (Linfield).

(Dundee Evening Telegraph: February 1, 1895)
